2565.42.text:
If somebody's
asking a question, I

2566.84.text:
want to be the one answering
it, not having somebody else.

2570.49.text:
But it turns out a lot of
other people feel differently.

2573.55.text: They love having that chat box.

2575.12.text:
And so, they really use it,
and they go to town with it.

2577.99.text:
And I have to admit,
it's value added.

2581.95.text:
And let's see, just
try to accommodate

2588.32.text:
We try and follow those
with a 10-minute break.

2590.53.text:
And have no more than
three sessions a day,

2592.34.text:
or you're going to
lose your audience.

2595.20.text:
And in conclusion, I
think the main takeaways

2599.76.text:
for what we've learned from
the virtual institute model

2603.28.text:
is that by having longer
periods of funding--

2606.38.text:
the five-year funding--
that's long for a scientists

2609.80.text:
because usually they have to
write proposals for one or two,

2614.28.text:
And by giving them a larger
amount of funding-- the teams

2617.76.text:
each get roughly
$1.2 million a year.

2620.45.text:
And this enables them to
then support their students.

2624.95.text:
You can support a
student for five years

2626.86.text:
and get them all the way
through graduate school,

2629.30.text: if they start at the right time.

2631.43.text:
But by doing this we get
unexpected discoveries

2634.70.text:
from the interdisciplinary
and inter-team collaboration

2639.07.text:
that comes about
through this research.

2640.97.text:
So the whole really is more
than the sum of the parts.

2644.67.text:
And we see incredible
productivity from these teams.

2647.61.text:
So we know that the taxpayer,
all of you, all of us,

2650.78.text:
are getting a lot of
bang for you buck.

2653.34.text:
The ability to assemble the
best possible team regardless

2658.57.text:
and the cost savings
that you get, obviously,

2661.14.text:
by not having to
travel everywhere,

2663.18.text:
both in time and
energy, really, I think,

2668.43.text:
And the long-term
stability for the students,

2670.43.text:
our future workforce, this
is so important to all of us.

2673.74.text:
So with that, I think
that's everything I brought.

2676.97.text:
And I'm happy to
answer any questions.

2680.20.text:
And we've got, of course,
Brian Day and Brad Bailey

2683.20.text:
here as well that are also
happy to take your questions.

2686.36.text:
AUDIENCE: Is NASA the
first organization

2691.09.text:
I thought it would have
been very popular by now.

2694.05.text:
YVONNE PENDLETON: Well,
that's a good question.

2699.78.text:
I think their model is
slightly different from ours.

2702.30.text:
But I do believe
NASA was the first.

2705.01.text:
And I think with the NASA
Astrobiology Institute,

2708.74.text:
they have the longest running
history, from 1998 to now.

2714.14.text:
So we took a lot of our
cues from what the NAI did.

2717.49.text:
And I think the NSF, it
probably learned a bit

2722.97.text: from what NASA did as well.

2725.64.text:
But I don't know of
other organizations.

2728.22.text:
I can tell you that both the
Office of Management and Budget

2731.76.text:
and the White House had been
interested in what we're doing.

2734.61.text:
And just about a
month or two ago,

2736.30.text:
they asked me to get them
a presentation as well,

2738.45.text:
because they're looking
at how this might

2742.41.text:
So you might see more virtual
institutes in the future.

2746.47.text:
AUDIENCE: So what's the
typical collaboration schedule

2751.91.text:
Do they all get together
like weekly or monthly,

2754.72.text:
or is it just like the PIs,
or is it the whole ecosystem?

2759.55.text:
YVONNE PENDLETON:
That's a great question.

2762.05.text:
So the question, it could
be answered differently

2767.16.text:
They are allowed to
set their own schedule

2769.61.text: and do what works best for them.

2771.99.text:
But I know some
teams that have--

2774.47.text:
almost all teams have at
least a monthly meeting,

2776.84.text:
in addition to the
monthly meeting

2778.26.text:
that they have with us
at the central office.

2780.78.text:
All the PIs get
together and report

2782.86.text:
on what their teams have
been doing once a month.

2784.97.text:
But within their team, they
do at least once a month,

2787.59.text: some of them on a weekly basis.

2789.72.text:
And I think it really depends
on whether their people are all

2793.32.text:
co-located in one place, or
whether they're spread out

2796.18.text:
and they need to tag up
with them around there.

2799.72.text:
But one of the
things that we think

2801.24.text:
is very important in running
the virtual institute

2804.32.text:
is not to over constrain
what the teams do.

2807.97.text:
As a scientist myself,
I know that I really

2810.86.text:
appreciate the leadership
getting the obstacles out

2814.26.text:
of the way and letting
me get my job done.

2816.34.text:
And that's what we're trying
to do with the teams as well.

2819.11.text:
So when they have new
directions, new ideas that they

2821.36.text:
want to go down, they
don't have to check in

2823.22.text:
with us every
minute of every day.

2825.36.text:
If it's a major
redirect, we'd like

2827.26.text:
them to talk to
us about it first.

2829.55.text:
But in general,
if all they do is

2832.61.text:
what they wrote
in their proposal,

2835.78.text:
Because we know that new
science, and new creativity,

2838.25.text:
and new ideas come
at the intersection

2842.97.text:
And those clever
ideas that they get

2845.01.text:
by having these weekly
or monthly discussions,

2849.11.text:
however often they
want to do it.

2852.64.text:
AUDIENCE: So I know a
lot of other NASA groups

2859.12.text:
Many of the Cassini, things
like that, all that groups

2865.07.text:
Do you think you could
give advice face to them as

2870.53.text:
to whether such-- everybody
needs to get together

2873.55.text:
in the same room
is still necessary.

2875.47.text:
Or do you think those
face-to-face meetings still

2878.84.text:
Or do you think
this is the future?

2880.30.text:
YVONNE PENDLETON: Sure,
a very important message.

2882.34.text:
I'm so glad you
asked that question.

2883.84.text:
Because a very important
message to take away here also

2886.70.text:
is that virtual is
not always the answer.

2889.36.text:
And there are some
really important reasons

2892.32.text:
and situations where you want
to have that face-to-face.

2895.51.text:
And I know from the
team activities,

2900.01.text:
my husband, who is also
a planetary scientist,

2903.91.text:
And I've watched
what they have to do

2906.68.text:
and the way that they
have to interact.

2908.30.text:
And right now
they're getting ready

2909.76.text:
for the Pluto
encounter that's going

2914.68.text:
They're meeting on a regular
basis in person, every month,

2918.66.text:
or every three to four weeks,
maybe even more frequent.

2922.20.text:
See OK, you're
part of that maybe?

2927.84.text:
And we are not by
any means suggesting

2929.88.text:
that this replace
those critical times.

2932.59.text:
But there are plenty
of other times

2934.20.text:
where we find that
virtual does work great.

2936.64.text:
And people ought to
be open minded to it

2939.97.text:
Also, I think the problem is
that when they think virtual,

2942.99.text:
they might think of some
bad experience they had

2945.80.text:
where the audio was
poor, the video was poor,

2948.53.text:
you wasted a lot of time
trying to get people set up.

2951.49.text: That is not what we do.

2953.11.text:
Come and watch one of our
video archived sessions,

2957.20.text:
or join us for something, and
you'll see the difference.

2959.88.text:
And part of that
difference is because we

2961.59.text:
have a technical staff
in the central office

2964.82.text:
that provides the bridging among
whatever platform you choose

2968.86.text:
to join in by, or the practicing
with the presenters ahead

2973.76.text:
They try to debug it,
so that to the audience

2977.30.text:
And the audio quality is high,
and the video quality is high.

2980.93.text:
And your experience
is much better.

2982.41.text:
Your frustration
level goes way down.

2984.32.text:
So there are some cases where
it works exceedingly well,

2987.57.text:
and other places
where I wouldn't

2989.28.text:
try to replace the
old fashioned way.

2992.61.text:
Well, thank you
very much Yvonne.

2995.72.text: It's a pleasure to be here.
